bioghist.p: Richardson Dilworth (1898-1974), was an American Democratic Party politician, born in the Pittsburgh area, who served as the 116th Mayor of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania from January 2, 1956 until his resignation in 1962 to run for Governor, a race in which he was defeated by William Scranton. Along with Joseph S. Clark and others, he was at the forefront of a post-World War II reform movement in Philadelphia which led to the adoption of a modern city charter that consolidated city and county offices and introduced civil service examinations on a broad scale to replace much of the existing patronage structure. During their tenures as mayor, Clark and Dilworth introduced a variety of reforms and innovations, including extensive high-rise public housing which, a generation later, was condemned by many as a breeding ground for poverty and crime. However, they also greatly strengthened the city planning function of Philadelphia city government. Both retained Edmund Bacon as Executive Director of the Philadelphia City Planning Commission, and this era is recognized as a high water mark for planning, the era when Center City Philadelphia's future as a commercial and residential center was rescued from decline. Dilworth's Administration made a priority of saving the city's historic and irreplaceable Society Hill district. Following his tenure as Mayor, he served as Partner in the Philadelphia-based law firm of Dilworth Paxson LLP, which bears his name. He also served as president of the Philadelphia school board, and in 1971 was appointed one of two bankruptcy trustees (along with Andrew L. Lewis, Jr.) for the Reading Company, the railroad company headquartered in Philadelphia.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers of Richardson Dilworth. Materials include: alphabetical subject files; public statements; files related to jury cases, jury charges, and law cases; subject files of Dilworth, mainly from the "Ps" -- Prisons, Playgrounds, Police, and the Port of Philadelphia.; subject files including extensive correspondence and files on City planning, housing, the fire department, and "City Issues‚Äù. Other materials include: notes and short letters from Richardson Dilworth to his wife, Ann; check stub book from 12/30/1968 to 11/7/69; 5"x7" black and white photograph of Richardson with two women just after deplaning (one is probably his wife Ann); photographs of Richardson Dilworth, including 6 originals and about 115 copy prints (some duplicates). There is also a small file of clippings about his daughter Deborah, and several about Dilworth. The collection also includes: several folders of Dilworth's correspondence with friends, 1944-1974, typescripts of speeches by Dilworth, 1947-1951; undated negatives; letter and photograph about the Dilworth Memorial in Dilworth Plaza, 1985; papers related to the naming and dedication of the Richardson Dilworth International Terminal at Philadelphia International Airport; a typed copy of a Marine Corps citation given to Dilworth "for gallantry and intrepidity in action" in 1943; and an album of photographs documenting The Philadelphia Award dinner, April 15, 1968. Scrapbooks and photo albums include: a Richardson Dilworth memorial scrapbook (1974), Dilworth's student and war scrapbook (ca. 1915-1926), Lees family photographs, (ca. 1960), Dilworth memorials (1974), social events scrapbook (1881-1946), and "G.S.P. photo album (ca. 1925).
